Introduction

Vertebral compression fracture (VCF) is characterized by collapse of one or more vertebral bodies under excessive mechanical stress, often due to decreased bone mineral density.  It is common in patients with osteoporosis, most commonly occurring in the thoracic and lumbar spine, but can also occur in other bone disorders and occasionally in healthy individuals.  Although VCF is often asymptomatic, it can cause significant pain, disability, and, in severe cases, neurologic complications.  Understanding the pathophysiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, diagnosis, and management of VCF is necessary for effective patient care.

Pathophysiology



VCF is typically caused by a combination of factors:



  • Osteoporosis:  Decreased bone mineral density weakens the vertebral body, making it more susceptible to fracture.
  • Trauma:  Direct or indirect trauma, such as falls or lifting heavy objects, can apply excessive stress to the spine.
  • Vertebral body abnormalities:  Preexisting conditions such as osteolytic lesions or spinal tumors can weaken the vertebral body.


The biomechanical process of VCF most often involves the collapse of the anterior vertebral body, resulting in a wedge-shaped deformity.  This collapse can compress the spinal canal, potentially leading to nerve root compression or spinal cord injury.

Risk factors



VCF is typically seen as a complication of osteoporosis; therefore, factors that contribute to age-related bone loss are associated with increased risk for VCF.  Major factors include:



  • Age and sex:  VCF is common with increasing age (prevalence of ~25% in females age â‰¥50); females are more likely to develop osteoporosis and VCF than males.
  • Hormonal factors:
    • Hypoestrogenism:  menopause, hypogonadism, oophorectomy/orchiectomy, functional hypothalamic amenorrhea, hyperprolactinemia
    • Nonâ€’estrogen-related conditions:  hyperthyroidism (increased bone turnover), Cushing syndrome, diabetes mellitus
  • Genetics:  family history of osteoporosis or VCF
  • Lifestyle factors:  smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, sedentary lifestyle
  • Medical conditions:  chronic inflammation (eg, rheumatoid arthritis), malabsorptive disorders (eg, celiac disease, Crohn disease), multiple myeloma
  • Medications:  corticosteroids, anticonvulsants, proton pump inhibitors, GnRH analogues

Pathology



VCF typically presents as a wedge-shaped deformity of the vertebral body, with the anterior height significantly decreased compared to the posterior height (

image 1
).  The fracture line may be transverse, oblique, or comminuted.  In severe cases, the vertebral body can completely collapse.

Clinical presentation



VCF occurs most commonly in postmenopausal women with low bone density and may occur following minimal trauma, such as bending, twisting, or falling from standing height.  It can also occur in patients with normal bone density, although usually in the context of more severe trauma (eg, falling from an extreme height).

Acute features



  • Sudden-onset focal back pain, often worse with standing, walking, or lying on the back
  • Pain that may radiate to the abdomen or flank
  • Point tenderness at affected vertebrae
  • Gradual improvement over 4-6 weeks

Chronic features



  • Insidious and progressive:  Asymptomatic cases may be confirmed on imaging performed for other reasons or with vertebral fracture assessment (VFA) as part of screening bone density testing (DXA).
  • Spinal deformity:  kyphosis, loss of height.
  • Abnormal loading of the spine:  This feature caused by VCF may lead to degenerative spondylosis and facet arthritis.
  • Neurologic symptoms:  In severe cases, VCF can compress neurologic structures, leading to radiculopathy (nerve root pain) or myelopathy (spinal cord compression).  Symptoms of radiculopathy may include numbness, tingling, weakness, and pain in the extremities.  Symptoms of myelopathy may include leg weakness, loss of bowel or bladder control, and difficulty walking.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of VCF is typically based on a combination of clinical history and physical examination, and confirmed with imaging studies (

image 2
).  Imaging options include the following:



  • X-ray is typically employed as an initial study for symptomatic fracture.
  • VFA is used to visualize the spine during DXA testing to reveal asymptomatic compression fractures.  It has high sensitivity for moderate to severe compression fracture, but sensitivity for mild compression is less than with standard x-ray studies.
  • CT scan or MRI is occasionally used to evaluate complex fractures or differentiate between osteoporotic and metastatic bone lesions.  MRI is suitable for visualization of neurologic structures.


VCF following low-velocity trauma in a postmenopausal woman establishes the diagnosis of osteoporosis, even without a formal measurement of bone density.  However, DXA should be performed nonurgently to guide chronic management and follow the course over time.  In addition, a basic laboratory evaluation for secondary causes of osteoporosis (eg, TSH, serum chemistries, 25-hydroxyvitamin D) is usually appropriate, especially in younger patients, men, and those with unexpectedly severe osteoporosis.

Differential diagnosis



  • Osteolytic lesions:  Metastatic cancer, multiple myeloma, and lymphoma can cause vertebral body collapse.
  • Infectious processes:  Osteomyelitis and tuberculosis can lead to vertebral body destruction.
  • Spinal tumors:  Primary spinal tumors, such as osteosarcoma or chondrosarcoma, can cause vertebral body collapse.
  • Herniated intervertebral disc:  Herniated disc can mimic the pain of VCF, especially if it compresses a nerve root.
  • Spondylolisthesis (
    image 3
    ):  Forward slippage of one vertebra on another can cause back pain and neurologic symptoms.

Management



Initial management of pain following VCF includes simple analgesics (eg, acetaminophen, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), or opioid analgesics if pain is more severe.  If pain persists, calcitonin nasal spray can provide additional relief (

).  However, skeletal muscle relaxants are generally not recommended due to adverse effects (eg, drowsiness, impaired balance) that are magnified in the elderly population.  A spinal brace is sometimes used in the initial management, but evidence to support this practice is limited and largely negative.  Chronic bracing is likely harmful due to possible atrophy of abdominal and paraspinal muscles.



Patients with VCF should be encouraged to ambulate and resume normal activity as soon as possible.  After pain is controlled and the patient is ambulating adequately, a dedicated course of physical therapy to address core strengthening and gait training for fall prevention can be implemented.  Secondary preventive measures include exercise (eg, flexibility and balance exercises, resistance training), management of the underlying osteoporosis (eg, bisphosphonates, calcium, vitamin D), and avoidance of lifestyle risk factors (eg, smoking).



Pain from acute VCF usually improves within 4-6 weeks.  Patients with refractory pain lasting >6 weeks can be considered for vertebral augmentation (eg, vertebroplasty, kyphoplasty), but these procedures are not recommended acutely.



  • Vertebroplasty involves injecting a cement-like substance into the fractured vertebral body to stabilize it and reduce pain.
  • Kyphoplasty is similar to vertebroplasty and involves injecting a balloon into the fractured vertebral body to restore height before injecting cement.
  • Spinal fusion is used in severe cases with neurologic complications or instability; it may be necessary to stabilize the spine.

Complications



  • Neurologic complications:  VCF can lead to nerve root compression or spinal cord injury, resulting in numbness, tingling, weakness, or loss of bowel or bladder control.
  • Pain:  VCF can cause persistent or recurrent back pain, often due to degenerative changes in the discs and facet joints that result from abnormal loading of the spine.
  • Deformity:  VCF can lead to a loss of height and kyphosis (hunchback posture), which, if severe, can impair breathing and intestinal function.

Prognosis



The prognosis for VCF varies depending on several factors, including severity of the fracture, presence of neurologic complications, and the patient's overall health and functional status.  Many patients with VCF experience significant improvement in pain and function with appropriate treatment.  However, the risk for recurrent VCF is high in those with osteoporosis.

Summary



Vertebral compression fracture (VCF) (

) is a common osteoporotic fracture that can cause significant pain, disability, and, in severe cases, neurologic complications.  Understanding the pathophysiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, diagnosis, and management of VCF is crucial for effective patient care.  Appropriate diagnosis and treatment can help improve symptoms and prevent complications.
